author: mwoodpatrick
body:
## Steps to reproduce

Run command: Update-Help

## Expected behavior
Should update docs

## Actual behavior

Gives:

Update-Help: Failed to update Help for the module(s) 'HgsClient, HgsDiagnostics' with UI culture(s) {en-US} : A Help URI cannot contain more than 10 redirections. Specify a valid Help URI..
English-US help content is available and can be installed using: Update-Help -UICulture en-US.
Update-Help: Failed to update Help for the module(s) 'WindowsUpdateProvider' with UI culture(s) {en-US} : One or more errors occurred. (Response status code does not indicate success: 404 (Not Found).).
English-US help content is available and can be installed using: Update-Help -UICulture en-US.

## Environment data

Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.0.3
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.0.3
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.20206
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0

comments.author: soccypowa
comments.body:
What is your UI cuture? Obviously there is a cmdlet for that nowadays: **Get-UICulture**.

What happend if you use the provided suggestion **Update-Help -UICulture en-US**?

I have to use the -UICulture switch as I am on sv-SE, but with the switch and having some of the sam modules from your error message, my help download completes. Issues with Update-Help I think is an issue more of the module and less of Powershell itself....

comments.author: mwoodpatrick
comments.body:
Get-UICulture reports:

> LCID             Name             DisplayName
> ----             ----             -----------
> 1033             en-US            English (United States)

Executing "Update-Help -UICulture en-US" reports:

> Update-Help: Failed to update Help for the module(s) 'HgsClient, HgsDiagnostics, WindowsUpdateProvider' with UI culture(s) {en-US} : One or more errors occurred. (An attempt was made to access a socket in a way forbidden by its access permissions.).
> English-US help content is available and can be installed using: Update-Help -UICulture en-US.

comments.author: kvprasoon
comments.body:
For WindowsUpdateProvider, refer https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/windows-powershell-docs/issues/139

Even the other modules doesn't looks like having valid help uri. @iSazonov /@SteveL-MSFT Do we already handle updating help files of modules where there is no or invalid help URIs ?

comments.author: vexx32
comments.body: Generally that's up to the individual teams that own the modules fixing the help URIs. Most of them are sorted out by now, but looks like there're still a few stragglers.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: Due to the fact that there are many modules, from time to time some help links may not work temporarily. Workaround `Update-Help -Force`.

comments.author: kvprasoon
comments.body: At least can we change the errors to warning in this case.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:
> At least can we change the errors to warning in this case.

Common PowerShell practice is to use `-ErrorAction`.

comments.author: kvprasoon
comments.body: Yes, but somehow I can't accept this as an error to ignore or continue :-)

comments.author: msftbot[bot]
comments.body: This issue has been marked as answered and has not had any activity for **1 day**. It has been closed for housekeeping purposes.

comments.author: mwoodpatrick
comments.body: Seems like just because some team has not updated their docs this should not leave the definition of what the current state of documentation is in an inconsistent/invalid state. State should define the latest available documentation for that module. I think this bug should be reopened

comments.author: MaximoTrinidad
comments.body:
Looks like we keep going in circles!

The command will only update the help for the ones it can find. Then, always ends in errors because of the ones not found.
It has been like this for the longest time.

So, no matter if you use the "-force" or the "-UICulture xxxx" parameter, it will always ends with errors. 
Sad! But True!

```
PowerShell 7.0.3
Copyright (c) Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.
                                                                                                                        https://aka.ms/powershell                                                                                               Type 'help' to get help.                                                                                                                                                                                                                        PS C:\Windows\System32> $PSVersionTable                                                                                 
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.0.3
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.0.3
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.20241
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0

PS C:\Windows\System32> update-help -force
Update-Help: Failed to update Help for the module(s) 'ConfigDefender, WindowsUpdateProvider' with UI culture(s) {en-US} : One or more errors occurred. (Response status code does not indicate success: 404 (Not Found).).
English-US help content is available and can be installed using: Update-Help -UICulture en-US.
Update-Help: Failed to update Help for the module(s) 'HgsClient, HgsDiagnostics' with UI culture(s) {en-US} : A Help URI cannot contain more than 10 redirections. Specify a valid Help URI..
English-US help content is available and can be installed using: Update-Help -UICulture en-US.
PS C:\Windows\System32>
PS C:\Windows\System32>
```

comments.author: thadguidry
comments.body:
@MaximoTrinidad Got it. So it is those 3 teams help files in my case that need to update or provide help.

In that case, this issue should be seen as an improvement in the messaging output here to users.  If you look at this output, the first sentence is nice and probably all that is needed. The remainder of sentences make the user feel as if they can indeed do something more to fix, but as you said...we can't!  So as others have said perhaps make it look like only a warning to us as users about only the failing modules and not much else.

Something like this should only be needed:
`Failed to update help on modules...xyz...this could be due to help files not available yet for those modules from our dev teams...but all other help files have updated successfully.`

How does that sound like a better idea and what this issue #13591 really involves?

comments.author: Jawz84
comments.body:
I am greatly in favour of @thadguidry 's suggestion of improving the end user communication as he describes. Current behaviour is throwing new users off. Example here: https://twitter.com/ShawnWildermuth/status/1336110172092162051?s=20
Twitter
Shawn Wildermuth 💻☕🎸🎥🎮 on Twitter
“@chris_noring @cecilphillip @theJasonHelmick Going through them now. Help won't install on my machine. Any ideas?”

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: The specific error message that en-US help is available, but really isn't should be fixed as I agree it's confusing to users.

comments.author: ScriptAutomate
comments.body:
People have been so confused about this for years that I gave a breakdown explanation of how `Update-Help` is working so that people can understand why they are getting errors, using this huge thread about the same problem: - https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/windows-powershell-docs/issues/139#issuecomment-554269636 And I'm definitely onboard with `Warning` messages replacing `Error` messages when it comes to broken `HelpInfoURI` endpoints, from a user perspective, otherwise users will continue to trip up on getting errors from the simple use of `Update-Help` which is often one of the first commands a person learns. Getting a large and unclear error message is really off-putting for new users, and my linked comment shows how an accepted answer on a Microsoft forum suggested _reinstalling Windows_ because of the error. The default way people run `Update-Help` for the past few years is something similar to this: ``` Update-Help -Verbose -Force -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue ``` Default functionality shouldn't be to "don't show me errors, just skip them," especially for new users, as it leads to bad practices and blind spots. Other places where I have engaged in discussion about this problem: - https://stackoverflow.com/questions/39834452/powershell-fails-with-update - https://www.reddit.com/r/PowerShell/comments/fcjkip/multiple_years_of_microsofts_broken_powershell/
Stack Overflow
Powershell fails with Update
When I run Update-Help it fails in Powershell. I am not going through a proxy. It is Direct Access. I am also running Powershell as an Admin. I am not sure what else to check for... Any advice is
reddit
Multiple Years of Microsoft's Broken PowerShell Module HelpInfoURIs and Update-Help
Have you tried using `Update-Help` on Windows PowerShell over the past few years? If you haven't in a while, go and do it now. I can tell you...

comments.author: joeyaiello
comments.body: /cc @sdwheeler and @theJasonHelmick that these are some we should get fixed as we work on updateable help pipeline stuff

comments.author: sdwheeler
comments.body:
@joeyaiello A while back I fixed all of the broken HelpInfoUri values that I could. There are currently 4 modules that are broken:

- ConfigDefender 
  - This is a Windows bug. They shipped a duplicate module (ConfigDefender.psd1) but the actual module is Defender.psd1 
- WindowsUpdateProvider
  - The FWLink points to the download package for the NetAdapter module
  - No package exists for this module
  - This will be fixed when we onboard to CabGen
- HgsClient
  - The target of the FWLink is missing the trailing `/`. This can be fixed if we can find the owner.
  - This will be fixed when we onboard to CabGen  
- HgsDiagnostics
  - The target of the FWLink is missing the trailing `/`. This can be fixed if we can find the owner.
  - This will be fixed when we onboard to CabGen

comments.author: theJasonHelmick
comments.body: @joeyaiello @sdwheeler, Sean and I are investigating how to deal with ConfigDefender, but we believe the other 3 will be handled when we onboard them to Cabgen. We may look to suppressing the error for ConfigDefender.

comments.body:
@sdwheeler I no longer see the errors for HgsClient or HgsDiagnostics, but PSReadline seems to have been added.

Update-Help: Failed to update Help for the module(s) 'ConfigDefender, PSReadline, WindowsUpdateProvider' with UI culture(s) {en-US} : One or more errors occurred. (Response status code does not indicate success: 404 (The specified blob does not exist.).).

comments.author: sdwheeler
comments.body:
PSReadLine is a known issue. I provided a workaround on the PowerShell team blog: https://devblogs.microsoft.com/powershell/updating-help-for-the-psreadline-module/
PowerShell Team
Updating help for the PSReadLine module | PowerShell Team
Updating help for the PSReadLine module You may have noticed an error message when trying to update the help for the PSReadLine module. In the example above, I am trying to update help for the PSReadLine module on my Windows computer.

comments.author: sdwheeler
comments.body:
@df1966 This is a known issue that there is no direct fix for. We blogged about this and there is a work around. See - https://devblogs.microsoft.com/powershell/updating-help-for-the-psreadline-module-in-windows-powershell-5-1/ - https://devblogs.microsoft.com/powershell/updating-help-for-the-psreadline-module/
PowerShell Team
Updating help for the PSReadLine module in Windows PowerShell 5.1 | PowerShell Team
Back in November of 2020 I posted instructions about how to work around the problem of updating the help for the PSReadLine module. The version of the PSReadline module that shipped in Windows PowerShell 5.1 used a lowercase letter in the name.
PowerShell Team
Updating help for the PSReadLine module | PowerShell Team
Updating help for the PSReadLine module You may have noticed an error message when trying to update the help for the PSReadLine module. In the example above, I am trying to update help for the PSReadLine module on my Windows computer.

comments.body: Thanks for responding.   It would seem to me that with all of their billions and the very long time this has been a known issue, they would have fixed it by now.

comments.author: Kev8144
comments.body: @ScriptAutomate's answer hides the unwanted "error" for me. Thanks!

comments.author: df1966
comments.body:
Thanks.  But as this had been a known issue for quite a while, I would think that it should have been fixed by now.
IMO, it's just pure laziness on their part to let something this simple of a fix (and not masking it) that could be done during a lunch break, to continue on in several updates as well.

comments.author: sdwheeler
comments.body:
@MaximoTrinidad the PSReadline issue is well known and documented. It will not be fixed in Windows until Server 2022. Please see 
- https://devblogs.microsoft.com/powershell/updating-help-for-the-psreadline-module-in-windows-powershell-5-1/
- https://devblogs.microsoft.com/powershell/updating-help-for-the-psreadline-module/

The other modules are known issues as well. The problem with those modules is outside of PowerShell. The module owners must fix them. We are working with them to get them fixed for the Server 2022 release.

comments.author: AnrDaemon
comments.body: The problem not in specific module, but in structure of the update process. It claims that en-US resource available, but unable to retrieve it. Also there's exactly zero debug information available for entire process.

comments.author: doctordns
comments.body: In this case it is a well know issue. Seems the update process is partly case sensitive, so PsReadline VS PsReadLine. The message is just trying to be helpful, although in this specific case, it isn’t.

comments.author: YoraiLevi
comments.body:
That's also mildly infuriating 
```ps1
PS> powershell.exe -Command "Update-Help -Force -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
PS> echo $LASTEXITCODE
1
```

comments.author: theJasonHelmick
comments.body:
There are modules that will, from time to time, be unavailable for updating. There are several reasons this might occur such as a module no longer being supported, a mistake in the helpinfouri, or a team that are not currently using the updatable help pipeline.  As teams choose to fix/not fix these issues, which would represent this the best in the output following update-help?
  
I've viewed the error messages as the most proper indication of what has occurred - however several here have requested that we change these to warnings.  If update-help can't locate a module to download, would you prefer to receive an error message or warning?

comments.author: YoraiLevi
comments.body:
> There are modules that will, from time to time, be unavailable for updating. There are several reasons this might occur such as a module no longer being supported, a mistake in the helpinfouri, or a team that are not currently using the updatable help pipeline. As teams choose to fix/not fix these issues, which would represent this the best in the output following update-help?
> 
> I've viewed the error messages as the most proper indication of what has occurred - however several here have requested that we change these to warnings. If update-help can't locate a module to download, would you prefer to receive an error message or warning?

I believe that the correct behavior should be errors in case modules became deprecated or urls die

BUT

At least for me and for others I have seen that this issue bothers them, it's the fact that when using a fresh windows install- update-help returns errors.

When a program I have just now started using screams at me "error" on first use I am suspicious if something is wrong with my setup.

yet everyone is acting like this is ok.

Something needs to be fixed and it's not about the error message

comments.author: AnrDaemon
comments.body:
> If update-help can't locate a module to download

If something fails, I want a usable error message that leads to a successful resolution of a problem, and a usable debug output I could rely upon.
"X fails but X available" is least useful, and complete absence of any debugging information does not help either.

comments.author: theJasonHelmick
comments.body:
There are several reasons that a module may fail to update help. The modules that the PowerShell team has influence over, we have corrected, however, there will be some modules that are not possible to immediately repair.  These modules may or may not be Microsoft modules.  I think most folks here have agreed, that if a module fails to update, the user should be informed of the failure.  Would it help if the error message were reduced and error details could be discovered with Get-Error - essentially hiding the details unless desired?  See sample image below:
![update-help](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12662278/172209097-6ff895c6-351d-4c1b-95ea-8d949c9a585e.png)

comments.author: mwoodpatrick
comments.body:
I don't want to see information hidden, If its expected that some modules don't have updates then a warning seems more appropriate. For example current message is

```
PS C:\Windows> Update-Help -UICulture en-US
Update-Help: Failed to update Help for the module(s) 'ConfigDefenderPerformance, DefenderPerformance, Dism, Get-NetView, Kds, LanguagePackManagement, NetQos, PcsvDevice, Pester, PKI, Whea, WindowsUpdate' with UI culture(s) {en-US} : One or more errors occurred. (Response status code does not indicate success: 404 (The specified blob does not exist.).).
English-US help content is available and can be installed using: Update-Help -UICulture en-US.

```
It would be clearer if it read

`Warning some modules don't have updates at this time: 'ConfigDefenderPerformance, DefenderPerformance, Dism, Get-NetView, Kds, LanguagePackManagement, NetQos, PcsvDevice, Pester, PKI, Whea, WindowsUpdate' with UI culture(s) {en-US} : `

comments.author: theJasonHelmick
comments.body: I'm investigating ways to improve the situation with Update-Help, so let me ask here: what if there was a way you could easily configure a 'block' list to prevent retrying an update for missing modules. The error messages would remain the same. This configurable list may initially ship with the modules that we know will not be updated in the future.  You can add additional modules if that is needed.  Would that be helpful?

comments.author: AnrDaemon
comments.body: A better diagnostic of backend response would help a lot more.

comments.author: theJasonHelmick
comments.body: @AnrDaemon - thank you!  Many of the errors you are receiving are modules that no longer have owners and will not be updated.  We think the block list may be a way to ship that knowledge so you don't have to troubleshoot.  As for additional problems with modules, is there a specific error message you've noticed not related to those mentioned in this issue?

title: Update-Help fails on Windows 10.0.20206
